comments:
This course investigates methods of economic analysis for decision making among alternative courses of action in engineering applications. Topics include: cost-driven design economics, break-even analysis, money-time relationships, rates of return, cost estimation, depreciation and taxes, foreign exchange rates, life cycle analysis, benefit-cost ratios, risk analysis, capital financing and allocation, and financial statement analysis. Case studies apply these topics to actual engineering problems.

Students thoroughly enjoyed the content of the course, agreeing that it was very challenging and rewarding. For many it was their first business-related class, and provided a “good basic primer/foundation for the fields of finance and accounting” and a “solid understanding of how individual businesses deal with money”. Many students enjoyed the case studies assignments, preferring to have more of them over the standard homework and readings which could get “tedious” at times. However, some felt that the case studies were too numerous and “hard to get used to”.

Students felt that Professor Cassel did an “impressive job teaching engineering students the mathematics of business”, even inspiring one student to pursue an Entrepreneurship minor. Professor Cassel was “easy to listen to and full of excellent and pertinent real-world experience”, as well as being “kind, understanding, and open for discussions”.

There was a general consensus on the heavy but rewarding workload of the course. This is a business-related course aimed at engineering students and required for majors, but recommended for non-majors as well.
